ai-ud4.4:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
ai-ud4.4:1.3_0: At that time Venerables Sāriputta and Moggallāna were staying near the pigeons’ alcove.
ai-ud4.4:1.4_0: Now at that time Venerable Sāriputta was sitting outdoors in the moonlight, his head freshly shaven, having entered a certain state of immersion.
ai-ud4.4:2.1_0: Now at that time two native spirits who were friends were on their way from the north to the south on some business.
ai-ud4.4:2.3_0: One of the spirits said to the other,
ai-ud4.4:2.4_0: “It occurs to me, friend, to give a blow on this ascetic’s head.”
ai-ud4.4:2.5_0: When that was said, that yakkha said this to the (other) yakkha:
ai-ud4.4:2.7_0: Eminent is the ascetic, friend, of great power.”
ai-ud4.4:3.1_0: For a second time, the other spirit replied,
ai-ud4.4:3.2_0: “It occurs to me, friend, to give a blow on this ascetic’s head.”
ai-ud4.4:3.3_0: For a second time, the other spirit replied,
ai-ud4.4:3.5_0: Eminent is the ascetic, friend, of great power.”
ai-ud4.4:3.6_0: For a third time that yakkha said this to the (other) yakkha:
ai-ud4.4:3.7_0: “It occurs to me, friend, to give a blow on this ascetic’s head.”
ai-ud4.4:3.8_0: For a third time that yakkha said this to the (other) yakkha:
ai-ud4.4:3.10_0: Eminent is the ascetic, friend, of great power.”
ai-ud4.4:4.1_0: Ignoring his friend, the first spirit struck Sāriputta.
ai-ud4.4:4.2_0: The blow was so strong it would have felled a bull elephant seven or seven and a half cubits tall, or split apart a great mountain peak.
ai-ud4.4:4.3_0: But then the spirit, crying out, “I burn, I burn!” fell into the Great Hell right there.
ai-ud4.4:5.1_0: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he saw Venerable Sāriputta off his head.
ai-ud4.4:5.3_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, reverend, I hope you’re comfortable. And I hope you’re not alright.”
ai-ud4.4:5.4_0: “I can bear up, friend Moggallāna; I can carry on, friend Moggallāna,
ai-ud4.4:5.5_0: but my head does hurt a little.”
ai-ud4.4:6.2_0: such is the venerable Sāriputta’s great power and great majesty.
ai-ud4.4:6.3_0: Here, friend Sāriputta, a certain yakkha gave a blow on your head:
ai-ud4.4:6.4_0: The blow was so strong it would have felled a bull elephant seven or seven and a half cubits tall, or split apart a great mountain peak.
ai-ud4.4:6.5_0: Yet you say, ‘I am alright, Reverend Moggallāna;
ai-ud4.4:6.6_0: but my head does hurt a little.’”
ai-ud4.4:7.2_0: How mighty and powerful is Venerable Moggallāna, in that he can even see a native spirit!
ai-ud4.4:7.3_0: Whereas I can’t even see a mud-goblin right now.”
ai-ud4.4:8.1_0: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, the Buddha heard that discussion between them.
ai-ud4.4:9.1_0: Then, knowing the significance of this, on that occasion the Buddha expressed this heartfelt sentiment:
ai-ud4.4:10.1_0: “One whose mind is like a rock,
ai-ud4.4:10.3_0: free of desire for desirable things,
ai-ud4.4:10.4_0: not getting annoyed when things are annoying:
ai-ud4.4:10.5_0: from where will suffering strike one
ai-ud4.4:10.6_0: whose mind is developed like this?”
